text:
So excited to find this site! I am currently in Florence- I just got here today from Sorrento ( also Mt. Vesuvius, Capri, Positano, Amalfi ) and previously was in Rome.

My daughter died last year in aआणखी senseless car accident and I’ve been traveling a LOT. I have a picture of her on the Spanish Steps so I went to that same spot and took one of me holding her photo. ❤️ I’m traveling with my son and his girlfriend and am just so happy to be here.

Because of this site, I just booked the pasta-making class in a couple days and am looking at other ideas as well, although our itinerary is pretty full. After here, we are going to Cinque Terre, Pisa, and finally—Venice. Does anyone know where I could maybe find a glass artist who would make something in glass using some of her ashes? ( i.e. paper weight? Or something like that?? )

Thanks in advance and here are a few photos of us and our Italian adventures so far!

text: Brits driving in Italy (more specifically sicily)….. what do I need to know? I’ve never driven in Europe before!

comments.comment_text:
We drove around Naples a couple of years ago, Italians (as a general rule) I found to be more “assertive” with their driving (compared to the French or Swiss).

If there’s a tiny gap between you and another car, it will soon be filled with a car bumper or scooter rider, which seem to come from either direction.

It’s a lot of fun driving in Italy, but you’ll need eyes in the back of your head.

My biggest adjustment was approaching roundabouts and remembering to look left and not right.

Just take your time initially and if possible avoid driving in any of the big cities as it can be very confusing and you will need eyes in the back of your head,

We have driven around Italy a few times now and for the most part it’s been a very enjoyable experience. If we wanted to visit any of the big cities like Florence or Naples we would drive to a small town a few miles outside and catch the train, it’s hard to find anywhere to park and we did receive a fine on one occasion for entering a restricted area .

Same as us Aussies, you'll need to adjust driving on the other side of the road.
Aussies need to get ourselves an international driver's licence, not sure if the Britts do too, so look into that.
We drove in Sicily (not me) but our husband's did. The first 10mins was crazy but they soon got into the swing of things & actually enjoyed it.
If you use Google maps as we did, you'll be deterred from streets you're not allowed into (residents only) or not allowed to park. Google helps decipher street signs too, and helps with speed limits. Goodluck 👍
Avoid driving in big cities, we italian drive like maniacs when stuck in traffic.
Get an automatic... or the first times you intend to change gear you'll end up opening the window! 😅

My son and I drive through Europe and Italy most years and find it better than driving in the UK.
If your driving down through France or Germany to get to Italy you'll adjust quite quickly to being on the right. Although roundabouts are the one thing that always seem to take longer to get used to! Plus even if you are on the roundabout cars joint will pull out just to through quicker.
If you are driving through France a lot of the motorways have tolls but they all take cards or cash. A lot of the non toll roads are only 2 lanes but are generally quieter.
Belgium and Germany don't have tolls and I've always found their motorways easy to travel along! Though all get busier near and around the bigger cities.
If you go through Switzerland or Austria you'll need a vignette to use the motorways. You can purchase the snal sticker at the borders or at fuel stations near the border. Although both now do electronic vignettes that just uses numberplate recognition.
In italy they do seem to think the motorways are just 1 big F1 track but just stay right till you get used to it. Again most motorways are only really busy near the cities and bigger towns. There are tolls again on the motorways but just head for the gates marked with a card or cash symbol and you'll be fine.
We tend not to drive in the cities as there are usually plenty of park and ride places plus parking in the city is difficult and there are nowore and more environmental zones in the cities where certain cars are not allowed.
If you haven't been before I'd recommend going over at least 1 alpine pass into Italy! The drive up and down is great and the views are always amazing 😁
Also make sure you have European breakdown cover and good travel insurance!

Don't be intimidated, keep within your comfort zone and use your mirrors. Give yourself space. Autostrade have two lanes, unlike the three in the UK. I once drove a UK Beetle from Calais to Rome. Wonderful run. Only Genova and the continuous stretch of tunnels in Liguria to the Tuscan border needed some extra concentration and nerve. Sicily is fine.
